member.name: T:Stormpath.SDK.Account.AccountStatus
member.summary: Represents the various states an Account may be in.

member.name: F:Stormpath.SDK.Account.AccountStatus.Enabled
member.summary: A disabled account may not login to applications.

member.name: F:Stormpath.SDK.Account.AccountStatus.Disabled
member.summary: An enabled account may login to applications.

member.name: F:Stormpath.SDK.Account.AccountStatus.Unverified
member.summary: An unverified account is a disabled account that does not have a verified email address.

member.name: M:Stormpath.SDK.Account.AccountStatus.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new instance.

members.member:
Parses a string to an Account Status.
A string containing "enabled", "disabled", or "unverified" (matching is case-insensitive). The Account Status with the specified name. No match is found..

member.name: M:Stormpath.SDK.Account.IAccount.SetPassword(System.String)
member.summary:
Sets (changes) the account's password to the specified raw (plaintext) password. Only call this method if you legitimately want to set the account password directly. When possible, it is advisable to use Stormpath's account password reset email workflow instead.
After calling this method, you must call to propagate the change to the Stormpath servers.

member.name: M:Stormpath.SDK.AccountStore.IAccountStoreContainer`1.AddAccountStoreAsync(System.String,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Adds a new Account Store to this Application. The given string can either be an href or a name of a Directory or Group belonging to the current Tenant.

remarks.para: If the provided value is an href, this method will get the proper Resource and add it as a new AccountStore in this Application or Organization without much effort. However, if the provided value is not an href, it will be considered as a name. In this case, this method will search for both a Directory and a Group whose names equal the provided . If only one resource exists (either a Directory or a Group), then it will be added as a new AccountStore in this Application or Organization. However, if there are two resources (a Directory and a Group) matching that name, a will be thrown.

Note: When using names this method is not efficient as it will search for both Directories and Groups within this Tenant for a matching name. In order to do so, some looping takes place at the client side: groups exist within directories, therefore we need to loop through every existing directory in order to find the required Group. In contrast, providing the Group's href is much more efficient as no actual search operation needs to be carried out.

member.param: Either the href or name of the desired Directory or Group.
member.exception: The resource already exists as an account store in this Application or Organization.
The given matches more than one resource in the current Tenant.

Providing a name

member.name: T:Stormpath.SDK.Api.IApiKey
member.summary: An API Key is a secure random username/password pair attributed to an Account that can be used by the account to make secure requests to an API service.
member.remarks: An Account may have zero or more API Keys, and allowing multiple keys is often useful for key rotation strategies. For example, a new key can be generated while an existing key is in use. Applications can then reference the new key (e.g., on startup), and once running, the old key can then be deleted. This allows for key rotation without an interruption in service, which would happen otherwise if an old key was invalidated the instant a new key was generated.

member.summary: Gets the raw secret used for API authentication.

remarks.para: A very secret, very private value that should never be disclosed to anyone other than the actual account holder. The secret value is mostly used for computing HMAC digests, but can also be used as a password for password-based key derivation and encryption.

member.value: The API Key plaintext secret.

member.name: T:Stormpath.SDK.Application.IApplicationAccountStoreMapping
member.summary: An represents the assignment of an Account Store (either a Group or Directory) to an Application.
member.remarks:
When an is created, the Accounts in the Account Store are granted access to become users of the linked Application. The order in which Account Stores are assigned to an Application determines how login attempts work in Stormpath.
Additionally, an may be designated as the default Account Store. This causes any accounts created directly by the Application to be dispatched to and saved in the associated Account Store, since Application cannot store Accounts directly.
Similarly, an may be designated as the default Group Store. This causes any Groups created directly by the Application to be dispatched to and saved in the associated Account Store, since an Application cannot store Groups directly. Note: A Group cannot store other Groups. Therefore, the default group store must be a Directory.

member.summary: A Builder design pattern used to construct instances.

member.name: M:Stormpath.SDK.Cache.ICacheConfigurationBuilder.WithTimeToLive(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Sets the associated Cache region's entry Time to Live (TTL).

remarks.para: Time to Live is the amount of time a cache entry may exist after first being created before it will expire and no longer be available. If a cache entry ever becomes older than this amount of time (regardless of how often it is accessed), it will be removed from the cache as soon as possible.

If this value is not configured, it is assumed that the Cache's entries could potentially live indefinitely. Note however that entries can still be expunged due to other conditions (e.g. memory constraints, Time to Idle setting, etc).

member.param: The entry Time to Live for this cache region.

member.name: M:Stormpath.SDK.Cache.ICacheConfigurationBuilder.WithTimeToIdle(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Sets the associated Cache region's entry Time to Idle (TTI).

remarks.para: Time to Idle is the amount of time a cache entry may be idle (unused/not accessed) before it will expire and no longer be available. If a cache entry is not accessed at all after this amount of time, it will be removed from the cache as soon as possible.

If this value is not configured, it is assumed that the Cache's entries could potentially live indefinitely. Note however that entries can still be expunged due to other conditions (e.g.memory constraints, Time to Live setting, etc).

member.param: The entry Time to Idle for this cache region.

member.summary: Enumeration that defines the available HTTP authentication schemes to be used when communicating with the Stormpath API server. The Authentication Scheme setting is helpful in cases where the code is run in a platform where the header information for outgoing HTTP requests is modified and thus causing communication issues. For example, for Google App Engine you need to set in order for your code to properly communicate with Stormpath API server. There are currently two authentication schemes available: HTTP Basic Authentication () and Digest Authentication ().

member.name: T:Stormpath.SDK.Client.IClientBuilder
member.summary: Represents a builder that can configure and construct Client instances.

remarks.para:
The Stormpath SDK can be configured in a variety of ways. The methods on IClientBuilder can be used to set configuration, but configuration options can also be loaded from a variety of sources. (Further documentation is available at Stormpath SDK Configuration Spec
Default configuration/fallback
apiKey.properties file from the ~/.stormpath directory
stormpath.json or stormpath.yaml file from the ~/.stormpath directory
apiKey.properties file from the application directory
stormpath.json or stormpath.yaml file from the application directory
Environment variables prefixed by STORMPATH_ (for example, STORMPATH_CLIENT_APIKEY_ID)
Configuration provided by the IClientBuilder convenience methods, or .

This builder provides a number of optional methods that fall back to sensible defaults:
If API credentials are not set manually using or , the default locations will be searched to discover an API Key (see above).
If is not called, the default scheme (SAuthc1) will be used.
If is not called, an in-memory cache will be used to improve performance, with a default TTL (Time to Live) and TTI (Time to Idle) of 1 hour. Caching can be disabled by passing to .
remarks.note: Note: The default in-memory cache might not be sufficient for an application that runs on multiple servers, due to cache-coherency issues. If your application runs in multiple instances, consider plugging in a distributed cache like Redis.

member.name: M:Stormpath.SDK.IdSite.IIdSiteAsyncCallbackHandler.SetNonceStore(Stormpath.SDK.IdSite.INonceStore)
member.summary: Sets a that will retain ID Site message identifiers as cryptographic nonces, eliminating the possibility of a replay attack. This ensures any ID Site message cannot be intercepted and used again later.

remarks.para: Because this ensures strong security, a is enabled by default if you have caching enabled for the SDK: a cache region will be used to store nonces over time, and those nonces will be used to assert that ID Site replies are not used more than once.

Default Nonce Store: A Cache-based is enabled by default if you have caching enabled in the SDK. Because nonces are stored in a cache region, it is very important to ensure that the nonce store cache region has an entry TTL longer than the response message valid life span. For Stormpath, response messages are valid for 1 minute, so your default cache region settings must use a TTL longer than 1 minute (most caching system defaults are ~ 30 minutes or an hour, so odds are high that you're okay).

Custom Nonce Store: If you have not enabled caching in the SDK, or you don't want to use your SDK cache as a nonce store, you can specify a custom instance via this method, and all ID Site reply identifiers will be stored there to prevent reuse, but note: your custom implementation MUST support the notion of a TTL (Time-to-Live) and automatically evict entries older than the max age lifespan (again, 1 minute).
If your implementation does not support TTL auto-eviction, your store will fill up indefinitely, likely causing storage errors.

member.param: The implementation to use when processing this request.

member.name: T:Stormpath.SDK.IdSite.INonceStore
member.summary: Store values and provides methods to check if a nonce has already been used, and to add it to the to ensure that the same nonce cannot be used again.
member.remarks:
implementations MUST support time to live (TTL) policies and automatic eviction of entries * that are older than a configured TTL.If an implementation does not support TTL eviction, the store will fill up indefinitely over time, likely causing storage errors.
Because of the TTL requirement, most NonceStore implementations delegate to a Caching API that supports TTL eviction.
NOTE:If you enable caching in the Stormpath SDK, the SDK will automatically enable a default cache-based NonceStore implementation for you. Just ensure that your caching configuration uses a default cache TTL slightly greater than 1 minute (the valid lifespan of a ID Site reply message).

member.name: T:Stormpath.SDK.Oauth.IJwtAuthenticator
member.summary: Represents a an OAuth 2.0 Authenticator used to authenticate a JSON Web Token against Stormpath.
member.remarks: This validation is performed against the Stormpath server. If you want to validate the token locally (no network request), call the method before performing the authentication.

member.name: M:Stormpath.SDK.Oauth.IJwtAuthenticator.WithLocalValidation(Stormpath.SDK.Oauth.JwtLocalValidationOptions)
member.summary: Instructs the authenticator to use local validation rather than making a network call to the Stormpath API.
member.remarks:
Local validation is faster as there is no network traffic involved. However, using Stormpath to validate the token ensures that the token can be validated against the state of your application and account.
Local validation ensures
Token hasn't been tampered with
Token hasn't expired
Issuer is Stormpath
Remote validation ensures
All criteria of local validation, plus:
Token hasn't been revoked
Account hasn't been disabled, and hasn't been deleted
Issuing application is still enabled, and hasn't been deleted
Account is still in account store for the issuing application
When validating access tokens issued by ID Site, local validation will fail because the Issuer (iss) claim is does not match the Application (for ID Site tokens, the issuer is the ID Site URL). In this case, you can manually specify the expected issuer with .
If validation fails, AuthenticateAsync() will throw the appropriate exception derived from .
member.param: Optional parameters to use when validating locally.

member.name: T:Stormpath.SDK.Organization.IOrganization
member.summary: An Organization is a top-level container for Directory and Group resources, and is an Account Store that can be mapped to an Application just like a Directory or Group.
member.remarks: Organizations are primarily intended to represent tenants in multi-tenant applications.

member.name: P:Stormpath.SDK.Organization.IOrganization.Name
member.summary: Gets the Organization's name.
member.value: The Organization's name. An Organization's name must be unique across all Organizations within a Stormpath Tenant.

member.name: P:Stormpath.SDK.Organization.IOrganization.NameKey
member.summary: Gets the Organization's name key.
member.value: The Organization's name key. An Organization's name key must be unique across all Organizations within a Stormpath Tenant, and must follow DNS hostname rules: it may only consist of a-z, A-Z, 0-9 and - (hyphen). It must not start or end with a hyphen. The uniqueness constraint is case-insensitive.

member.name: P:Stormpath.SDK.Organization.IOrganization.Status
member.summary: Gets the Organization's status.
member.value: The Organization's status. Enabled Organizations can be used as Account Stores for Applications; Disabled Organizations cannot.

member.summary: Gets the Organization's description.
member.value: The description of the Organization.

member.summary: Sets the Organization's name.
member.param: The Organization's name. Organization names must be unique within a Stormpath Tenant.

member.name: M:Stormpath.SDK.Organization.IOrganization.SetNameKey(System.String)
member.summary: Sets the Organization's name key.
member.param: The Organization's name key. Organization name keys must be unique within a Stormpath Tenant, and must follow DNS hostname rules: it may only consist of a-z, A-Z, 0-9 and - (hyphen). It must not start or end with a hyphen. The uniqueness constraint is case-insensitive.

member.summary: Sets the Organization's description.

member.name: M:Stormpath.SDK.Organization.IOrganization.GetGroups
member.summary: Gets a queryable list of all Groups accessible to this Organization. It will not only return any group associated directly as an Account Store but also every Group that exists inside every Directory associated as an Account Store.
member.returns: An that may be used to list or search Groups.

member.name: T:Stormpath.SDK.Organization.IOrganizationAccountStoreMapping
member.summary: An represents the assignment of an Account Store (either a Group or Directory) to an Organization.
member.remarks:
When an is created, the Accounts in the Account Store are granted access to become users of the linked Organization. The order in which Account Stores are assigned to an Organization determines how login attempts work in Stormpath.
Additionally, an may be designated as the default Account Store. This causes any accounts created directly by the Organization to be dispatched to and saved in the associated Account Store, since Organizations cannot store Accounts directly.
Similarly, an may be designated as the default Group Store. This causes any Groups created directly by the Organization to be dispatched to and saved in the associated Account Store, since an Organization cannot store Groups directly. Note: A Group cannot store other Groups. Therefore, the default group store must be a Directory.

member.name: M:Stormpath.SDK.Organization.IOrganizationAccountStoreMapping.SetOrganization(Stormpath.SDK.Organization.IOrganization)
member.summary: Sets the Organization represented by this resource.
member.param: The Organization represented by this Account Store Mapping.

member.name: M:Stormpath.SDK.Organization.IOrganizationAccountStoreMapping.GetOrganizationAsync(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Gets the Organization represented by this mapping.

member.summary: Represents options for an Organization creation request.

member.name: P:Stormpath.SDK.Organization.IOrganizationCreationOptions.CreateDirectory
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether to create a new Directory along with the Organization.

value.para: If , a new Directory will be created. The new Directory will automatically be assigned as the Organization's default Account and Group store. If the property is not null, the new Directory will be created with that name. Otherwise, the Directory will be automatically named based on heuristics to ensure a guaranteed unique name based on the Organization.
If , no directory will be created.

member.name: P:Stormpath.SDK.Organization.IOrganizationCreationOptions.DirectoryName
member.summary: Gets the name to use when creating a new Directory for this Organization.
member.value: The name to assign to the new Directory. This only has an effect if is .

member.name: T:Stormpath.SDK.Saml.ISamlAsyncCallbackHandler
member.summary: Handles HTTP replies sent from a SAML Identity Provider to your application's callbackUri and returns an .

member.name: M:Stormpath.SDK.Saml.ISamlAsyncCallbackHandler.SetNonceStore(Stormpath.SDK.IdSite.INonceStore)
member.summary: Sets a that will retain message identifiers as cryptographic nonces, eliminating the possibility of a replay attack. This ensures any SAML Identity Provider response message cannot be intercepted and used again later.

remarks.para: Because this ensures strong security, a is enabled by default if you have caching enabled for the SDK: a cache region will be used to store nonces over time, and those nonces will be used to assert that SAML Identity Provider replies are not used more than once.

Default Nonce Store: A Cache-based is enabled by default if you have caching enabled in the SDK. Because nonces are stored in a cache region, it is very important to ensure that the nonce store cache region has an entry TTL longer than the response message valid life span. For Stormpath, response messages are valid for 1 minute, so your default cache region settings must use a TTL longer than 1 minute (most caching system defaults are ~ 30 minutes or an hour, so odds are high that you're okay).

Custom Nonce Store: If you have not enabled caching in the SDK, or you don't want to use your SDK cache as a nonce store, you can specify a custom instance via this method, and all ID Site reply identifiers will be stored there to prevent reuse, but note: your custom implementation MUST support the notion of a TTL (Time-to-Live) and automatically evict entries older than the max age lifespan (again, 1 minute).
If your implementation does not support TTL auto-eviction, your store will fill up indefinitely, likely causing storage errors.

member.param: The implementation to use when processing this request.
member.exception: is .

member.name: M:Stormpath.SDK.Tenant.ITenantActions.VerifyAccountEmailAsync(System.String,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Verifies an account's email address based on a sptoken parameter embedded in a URL found in an account's verification email.

remarks.para:
For example:
https://my.company.com/email/verify?sptoken=ExAmPleEmAilVeRiFiCaTiOnTokEnHeRE

Based on this URL, the following should be invoked:
tenant.VerifyAccountEmailAsync("ExAmPleEmAilVeRiFiCaTiOnTokEnHeRE");

member.exception: The token was not valid.
